properties.media:imagetext:
Kweiyang
Sunday March 31st
1935
Personal
& Confidential.
As I write
this letter I am seated in the small study room
of Dr.
Robinson of the China
Inland Mission at Kweiyangâ€¢
the room is a small kerosene lamp on the corner of the desk.
Accommodations are limited, as many refugee missionaries are in town
account of Communist activities in this province,
profuse apologies for having to put me up for
the night on a cot
This room is warmed by a charcoal fire built on a large
brass tray which in
turn rests on a wooden
frame about six inches off
the floor.
The cot takes up practically
all of the west side of the
On the wall above
are two large maps, one of Kweichow
Province and the other of China with
an"Index of Christian Missions",
the maps nailed to the
wall is a card 12 x 8 inches with
inscription "Motto for the Year"
under which
is reproduced a rather
gaudy bowl of flowers
printed in colors which in several places do not
clearly -
of like the Sunday comic pictures
- below the
"HE said PEACE - and
there was a great calm."
must have
meant that slogan,
for some other year!
The north wall is filled
mostly with book shelves partly inhabited with books.
A small card is
to a shalf.
It is a pink card with blue forget-me-nots forming
surrounding a fancy
type motto strangely reminiscent of
Clarence Howard "God 10 love."
My desk is against the east wall
decorated with more maps of the Province showing the branch
missions under the supervision of this one.
To the left is a 1955
issued by the Mellon National Bank of Pittsburgh,
that another motto - this one
burned wood "They that wait upon the
Lord shall renew their strength."
The south wall consists entirely
of French doors which open out onto a little garden bravely but poorly
Tacked to the left door is another sign
"I the Lora thy God will
hold thy right hand saying unto thee FEAR NOT."
In spite of this reasonind placard the wives of the mission-
aries stationed in this house and possibly the man also are being
evacuated tomorrow.
We flew over a group of Reds about 2000 strong
only 40 miles north of Kweiyang:
They have got in behind the Nation-
alists lines and have blown up bridges and stretches of road.
Reds or bandits move about with unbelievable rapidity.- groups defin-
itely located at a certain point will show up 40 miles away 24 hours
It is believed that they will attempt to take Kweiyang because
Chiang Kai-shek and his staff are here.
Several days ago the Reds
drew Chiang's troops away from Kweiyang retreating northward - then the
Reds made a quick reversment,
surprised a small force, crossed a river
which they were not supposed to be able to cross and
now are between
Chiang Kai-shek and the
main body of his army.
It's highly improbable
that the Reds will take Kweiyang but I am just as well satisfied to be
leaving in the morning:
We arrived at Kweiyang airport early this
afternoon - it is 20 miles south of the city
- but all of the few
automobiles and busses have been commandeered by the military and we
had to wait several hours for a
It was a Chevrolet chassis on
which a Chinese "custom built" body had been attached.
The "windows"
are of wood and the seats are 8 inch boards without backs.
The tires
are hard and the springs long since
collapsed.
Never have I taken
In Szechuen
such a beating.
near Chungking and in Chengtu all poppies - at least near roads - have
been ploughed under - but in Kweichow along the road from the airport
fields of poppies - the white blossoms just coming into bud - were
everywhere.
It is a wretched country.
They say that 95% of the
smoke opium.
The country is poor and the people poorer.
Along the road we saw many of the big-turbaned men and the quilted-skirt
women of the Miao - aboriginal tribes which existed before the coming
of the Chinese.
They have maintained their language and customs
through thousands of years.
Arriving Kweiyang we had to get out of
the bus (which was no hardship) at the gate to the city.
